column1: Dover () is the capital and second-largest city in the U.S. state of Delaware. It is also the county seat of Kent County
column2: and the principal city of the Dover
column4: which encompasses all of Kent County and is part of the Philadelphia-Wilmington-Camden

column2: the name derives from the Brythonic word for waters (dwfr in Middle Welsh). The same element is present in the town's French (Douvres) and Modern Welsh (Dofr) forms. The city is named after Dover

column1: Dover was founded as the court town for newly established Kent County in 1683 by William Penn
column2: the proprietor of the territory generally known as the "Lower Counties on the Delaware." Later
column4: the city was officially laid out by a special commission of the Delaware General Assembly. The capital of the state of Delaware was moved here from New Castle in 1777 because of its central location and relative safety from British raiders on the Delaware River. Because of an act passed in October 1779
column5: the assembly elected to meet at any place in the state they saw fit

column11: until it finally settled down permanently in Dover in October 1781. The city's central square
column13: was the location of many rallies
column15: and other patriotic events. To this day
column16: The Green remains the heart of Dover's historic district and is the location of the Delaware Supreme Court and the Kent County Courthouse.

column1: Dover was most famously the home of Caesar Rodney
column2: the popular wartime leader of Delaware during the American Revolution. He is known to have been buried outside Dover
column3: but the precise location of his grave is unknown. A cenotaph in his honor is erected in the cemetery of the Christ Episcopal Church near The Green in Dover.

column1: Dover and Kent County were deeply divided over the issue of slavery
column2: and the city was a "stop" on the Underground Railroad because of its proximity to slave-holding Maryland and free Pennsylvania and New Jersey. It was also home to a large Quaker community that encouraged a sustained emancipation effort in the early 19th century. There were very few slaves in the area

column1: Dover has a warm temperate climate or humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa). Summers are hot and humid
column2: with 23 days per year reaching or surpassing 90 °F (32 °C). Brief
column3: but heavy summer thunderstorms are common. Winters are moderated by the Delaware Bay and the partial shielding of the Appalachians
column4: though there are normally 8−9 days when the daily high remains below freezing and 15 nights with lows below 20 °F (−7 °C). Snow is typically light and sporadic
column5: averaging only 15.7 inches (40 cm) per season
column6: and does not usually remain on the ground for long. Spring and autumn provide transitions of reasonable length and are similar
column7: though spring is wetter. The monthly mean temperature ranges from 35.2 °F (1.8 °C) in January to 77.7 °F (25.4 °C) in July. The annual total precipitation of around 46 inches (1
column8: 170 mm) is spread rather evenly year-round. Dover averages 2300 hours of sunshine annually.

column1: Dover is governed via the council-manager system with an elected mayor
column2: currently Robin R. Christiansen since 2014. The council consists of nine members
column3: eight of whom are elected from four districts with each district having two members. One member of the council is elected at large. Municipal elections
column4: which are nonpartisan
column5: are held on the third Tuesday in April in odd-numbered years. The mayor is elected directly by the city voters for a four-year term. City council members are elected to staggered four-year terms.There have been four full-time Mayors of Dover to date: James "Hutch" Hutchison from 1994 to 2004; Stephen Speed from 2004 to 2007; Carleton Carey from 2007 to 2014; Robin R. Christiansen since 2014.

column1: The Dover Police Department provides police services to the city of Dover. The police department is led by a Chief of Police
column2: currently Thomas Johnson
column4: responding to 43
column5: 000 calls a year.  The Dover Police Department is composed of several sworn police units along with civilian units. Fire protection in Dover is provided by the Dover Fire Department
column6: a volunteer fire department which has served the city since 1882 and operates two stations in Dover. Station 1 is the department's headquarters and houses Engines 4
column8: and 7; Ladder 2; Rescue 1; Brush 9; and Marine 1. The Dover Fire Department Museum is also located at the headquarters. Station 2 houses Engines 2 and 3; Ladder 1; Utility 1; and the foam trailer.

column1: Dover is the only state capital in the United States with a volunteer fire department.

column1: Dover is one of the fast-growing areas in the state of Delaware
column2: due in large part to the relatively low cost of living. As a consequence
column3: the Kent County government is a major employer in the area as well. Apart from the state and county governments
column4: Dover's significant employers include Dover Air Force Base
column5: located within the southeast corporate limits of the city. The base houses two airlift wings as well as the U.S. military's only mortuary in the continental United States
column6: which accepts and processes the remains of soldiers killed in battle. In addition
column7: Kraft Foods and Procter & Gamble have manufacturing facilities in Dover. The Kraft Foods plant in Dover has been the plant that manufactures Jell-O since 1964 when it relocated from Bloomfield
column8: New York. The P&G plants makes Pampers Baby Fresh wipes. ILC Dover
column10: is the producer of fabrics for military and aerospace uses
column11: along with being the primary contractor for production of the Apollo and Skylab spacesuits
column12: as well as the spacesuit assembly for the Space Shuttle's Extravehicular Mobility Unit (EMU). Several local and national retailers and restaurants line US 13 through Dover
column13: with the Dover Mall situated along this corridor and serving as the only shopping mall in the area.

The main north–south highway through Dover is U.S. Route 13
column2: which runs through the main commercial strip of Dover on the multi-lane
column3: divided Dupont Highway. An alternate route of U.S. Route 13
column4: U.S. Route 13 Alternate
column5: passes through downtown Dover on Governors Avenue. The limited-access Delaware Route 1 toll road
column6: which provides the main route to Wilmington and the Delaware Beaches
column7: passes to the east of Dover. It ends near the Dover Air Force Base and DE 1 continues south on Bay Road. U.S. Route 113 formerly ran along Bay Road from Milford to US 13 near the State Capitol Complex
column8: however it was decommissioned north of Milford in 2004 to avoid the concurrency with DE 1 between the Dover Air Force Base and Milford. Delaware Route 8 is the main east–west route through Dover
column9: passing through downtown on Division Street and West Dover on Forrest Avenue. It continues west toward Maryland to provide access to the Chesapeake Bay Bridge. Delaware Route 15 passes north-south through the western part of Dover along Hazlettville Road
column12: and McKee Road. Dover is one of only four state capitals not served by an Interstate highway. Pierre
column15: Alaska are the other three state capitals with this distinction.Parking in the downtown area of Dover consists of free on-street two-hour parking and five off-street parking lots offering a total of 440 spaces. Parking lots in downtown Dover contain a mix of permit parking
column19: and handicapped parking spaces along with spaces reserved for tenants and apartments. Parking is free on evenings and weekends.Dover Air Force Base is located within the southeast corporate limits of Dover. Airports near Dover with commercial air service include the Wicomico Regional Airport in Salisbury
column21: the Baltimore-Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport in Baltimore
column22: and the Philadelphia International Airport in Philadelphia. Other general aviation airports near Dover include Chandelle Estates Airport to the northeast of the city

column1: Dover is located on a former Pennsylvania Railroad line

column1: The city of Dover provides various utility services to businesses and residents. The Department of Public Works provides trash collection
column2: recycling
column4: and sewer service to the city. Republic Services provides recycling collection under contract to the city. The City of Dover Electric Department provides electricity to the city and some surrounding areas to the south and east
column5: including the town of Little Creek. The city's electric department is a member of the Delaware Municipal Electric Corporation
column6: a wholesale electric utility that represents municipal electric departments in the state of Delaware. The City of Dover Electric Department generates some of its electricity from the McKee Run Generating Station
column7: which consists of three natural gas-powered units that are used on a limited basis. The city also generates electricity from solar power at the Dover SUN Park
column8: a 10 MW solar power farm on 103 acres at the Garrison Oak technology park that is owned by SunPower. The remainder of the city's electricity is purchased. Natural gas service in Dover is provided by Chesapeake Utilities.

column1: Bayhealth Medical Center operates the Bayhealth Hospital
